texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, although some mostly larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This powerful, robust species has a large mouth equipped with projecting canine teeth. Adult colour fairly plain reddish-bronze; juveniles reddish-orange with a black spot on the back behind the dorsal fin and near base of tail. In small juveniles the belly and peduncle of the tail are also bright yellow.
Up to 200 cm total length and a mass of 70 kg.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Adults found over rocky reefs in 20–160 m of water, juveniles occur more inshore in 10–30 m. A legendary angling fish that once formed an important component of both recreational and commercial line fisheries, but now severely overexploited and adults thus seldom seen. Usually solitary.  Only reaches sexual maturity at the large size of 58–75 cm and age of 7–9 years (making the species particularly vulnerable to overexploitation) and reaches an age of 55 years. IUCN Red List status Endangered.
Adults are voracious predators feeding on large prey such as cephalopods and other fish.
Spawning aggregations form in July-October off the Eastern Cape and the fish are particularly vulnerable to fishing exploitation at this time. Larvae pelagic and drift in the plankton.
Large size and colour pattern fairly distinctive but does vary considerably with age.
